14#ifndef ISCCFG_CFG_H
15#define ISCCFG_CFG_H 1
16
17/*****
18 ***** Module Info
19 *****/
20
21/*! \file isccfg/cfg.h
22 * \brief
23 * This is the new, table-driven, YACC-free configuration file parser.
24 */
25
26/***
27 *** Imports
28 ***/
29
30#include <inttypes.h>
31#include <stdbool.h>
32
33#include <isc/formatcheck.h>
34#include <isc/lang.h>
35#include <isc/refcount.h>
36#include <isc/types.h>
37#include <isc/list.h>
38
39/***
40 *** Types
41 ***/
42
43/*%
44 * A configuration parser.
45 */
46typedef struct cfg_parser cfg_parser_t;
47
48/*%
49 * A configuration type definition object. There is a single
50 * static cfg_type_t object for each data type supported by
51 * the configuration parser.
52 */
53typedef struct cfg_type cfg_type_t;
54
55/*%
56 * A configuration object. This is the basic building block of the
57 * configuration parse tree. It contains a value (which may be
58 * of one of several types) and information identifying the file
59 * and line number the value came from, for printing error
60 * messages.
61 */
62typedef struct cfg_obj cfg_obj_t;
63
64/*%
65 * A configuration object list element.
66 */
67typedef struct cfg_listelt cfg_listelt_t;
68
69/*%
70 * A callback function to be called when parsing an option
71 * that needs to be interpreted at parsing time, like
72 * "directory".
73 */
74typedef isc_result_t
75(*cfg_parsecallback_t)(const char *clausename, const cfg_obj_t *obj, void *arg);
76
77/***
78 *** Functions
79 ***/
80
81ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
82
83void
84cfg_parser_attach(cfg_parser_t *src, cfg_parser_t **dest);
85/*%<
86 * Reference a parser object.
87 */
88
89isc_result_t
90cfg_parser_create(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_log_t *lctx, cfg_parser_t **ret);
91/*%<
92 * Create a configuration file parser. Any warning and error
93 * messages will be logged to 'lctx'.
94 *
95 * The parser object returned can be used for a single call
96 * to cfg_parse_file() or cfg_parse_buffer(). It must not
97 * be reused for parsing multiple files or buffers.
98 */
99
100void
101cfg_parser_setcallback(cfg_parser_t *pctx,
102 cfg_parsecallback_t callback,
103 void *arg);
104/*%<
105 * Make the parser call 'callback' whenever it encounters
106 * a configuration clause with the callback attribute,
107 * passing it the clause name, the clause value,
108 * and 'arg' as arguments.
109 *
110 * To restore the default of not invoking callbacks, pass
111 * callback==NULL and arg==NULL.
112 */
113
114isc_result_t
115cfg_parse_file(cfg_parser_t *pctx, const char *file,
116 const cfg_type_t *type, cfg_obj_t **ret);
117
118isc_result_t
119cfg_parse_buffer(cfg_parser_t *pctx, isc_buffer_t *buffer,
120 const char *file, unsigned int line,
121 const cfg_type_t *type, unsigned int flags,
122 cfg_obj_t **ret);
123/*%<
124 * Read a configuration containing data of type 'type'
125 * and make '*ret' point to its parse tree.
126 *
127 * The configuration is read from the file 'filename'
128 * (isc_parse_file()) or the buffer 'buffer'
129 * (isc_parse_buffer()).
130 *
131 * If 'file' is not NULL, it is the name of the file, or a name to use
132 * for the buffer in place of the filename, when logging errors.
133 *
134 * If 'line' is not 0, then it is the beginning line number to report
135 * when logging errors. This is useful when passing text that has been
136 * read from the middle of a file.
137 *
138 * Returns an error if the file or buffer does not parse correctly.
139 *
140 * Requires:
141 *\li "filename" is valid.
142 *\li "mem" is valid.
143 *\li "type" is valid.
144 *\li "cfg" is non-NULL and "*cfg" is NULL.
145 *\li "flags" be one or more of CFG_PCTX_NODEPRECATED or zero.
146 *
147 * Returns:
148 * \li #ISC_R_SUCCESS - success
149 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY - no memory available
150 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE - file doesn't exist or is unreadable
151 *\li others - file contains errors
152 */
153
154isc_result_t
155cfg_parser_mapadd(cfg_parser_t *pctx, cfg_obj_t *mapobj,
156 cfg_obj_t *obj, const char *clause);
157/*%<
158 * Add the object 'obj' to the specified clause in mapbody 'mapobj'.
159 * Used for adding new zones.
160 *
161 * Require:
162 * \li 'obj' is a valid cfg_obj_t.
163 * \li 'mapobj' is a valid cfg_obj_t of type map.
164 * \li 'pctx' is a valid cfg_parser_t.
165 */
166
167void
168cfg_parser_reset(cfg_parser_t *pctx);
169/*%<
170 * Reset an existing parser so it can be re-used for a new file or
171 * buffer.
172 */
173
174void
175cfg_parser_destroy(cfg_parser_t **pctxp);
176/*%<
177 * Remove a reference to a configuration parser; destroy it if there are no
178 * more references.
179 */
180
181bool
182cfg_obj_isvoid(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
183/*%<
184 * Return true iff 'obj' is of void type (e.g., an optional
185 * value not specified).
186 */
187
188bool
189cfg_obj_ismap(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
190/*%<
191 * Return true iff 'obj' is of a map type.
192 */
193
194bool
195cfg_obj_isfixedpoint(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
196/*%<
197 * Return true iff 'obj' is of a fixedpoint type.
198 */
199
200bool
201cfg_obj_ispercentage(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
202/*%<
203 * Return true iff 'obj' is of a percentage type.
204 */
205
206isc_result_t
207cfg_map_get(const cfg_obj_t *mapobj, const char* name, const cfg_obj_t **obj);
208/*%<
209 * Extract an element from a configuration object, which
210 * must be of a map type.
211 *
212 * Requires:
213 * \li 'mapobj' points to a valid configuration object of a map type.
214 * \li 'name' points to a null-terminated string.
215 * \li 'obj' is non-NULL and '*obj' is NULL.
216 *
217 * Returns:
218 * \li #ISC_R_SUCCESS - success
219 * \li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND - name not found in map
220 */
221
222const cfg_obj_t *
223cfg_map_getname(const cfg_obj_t *mapobj);
224/*%<
225 * Get the name of a named map object, like a server "key" clause.
226 *
227 * Requires:
228 * \li 'mapobj' points to a valid configuration object of a map type.
229 *
230 * Returns:
231 * \li A pointer to a configuration object naming the map object,
232 * or NULL if the map object does not have a name.
233 */
234
235unsigned int
236cfg_map_count(const cfg_obj_t *mapobj);
237/*%<
238 * Get the number of elements defined in the symbol table of a map object.
239 *
240 * Requires:
241 * \li 'mapobj' points to a valid configuration object of a map type.
242 *
243 * Returns:
244 * \li The number of elements in the map object.
245 */
246
247bool
248cfg_obj_istuple(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
249/*%<
250 * Return true iff 'obj' is of a map type.
251 */
252
253const cfg_obj_t *
254cfg_tuple_get(const cfg_obj_t *tupleobj, const char *name);
255/*%<
256 * Extract an element from a configuration object, which
257 * must be of a tuple type.
258 *
259 * Requires:
260 * \li 'tupleobj' points to a valid configuration object of a tuple type.
261 * \li 'name' points to a null-terminated string naming one of the
262 *\li fields of said tuple type.
263 */
264
265bool
266cfg_obj_isuint32(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
267/*%<
268 * Return true iff 'obj' is of integer type.
269 */
270
271uint32_t
272cfg_obj_asuint32(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
273/*%<
274 * Returns the value of a configuration object of 32-bit integer type.
275 *
276 * Requires:
277 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of 32-bit integer type.
278 *
279 * Returns:
280 * \li A 32-bit unsigned integer.
281 */
282
283bool
284cfg_obj_isuint64(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
285/*%<
286 * Return true iff 'obj' is of integer type.
287 */
288
289uint64_t
290cfg_obj_asuint64(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
291/*%<
292 * Returns the value of a configuration object of 64-bit integer type.
293 *
294 * Requires:
295 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of 64-bit integer type.
296 *
297 * Returns:
298 * \li A 64-bit unsigned integer.
299 */
300
301uint32_t
302cfg_obj_asfixedpoint(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
303/*%<
304 * Returns the value of a configuration object of fixed point number.
305 *
306 * Requires:
307 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of fixed point type.
308 *
309 * Returns:
310 * \li A 32-bit unsigned integer.
311 */
312
313uint32_t
314cfg_obj_aspercentage(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
315/*%<
316 * Returns the value of a configuration object of percentage
317 *
318 * Requires:
319 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of percentage type.
320 *
321 * Returns:
322 * \li A 32-bit unsigned integer.
323 */
324
325bool
326cfg_obj_isstring(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
327/*%<
328 * Return true iff 'obj' is of string type.
329 */
330
331const char *
332cfg_obj_asstring(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
333/*%<
334 * Returns the value of a configuration object of a string type
335 * as a null-terminated string.
336 *
337 * Requires:
338 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of a string type.
339 *
340 * Returns:
341 * \li A pointer to a null terminated string.
342 */
343
344bool
345cfg_obj_isboolean(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
346/*%<
347 * Return true iff 'obj' is of a boolean type.
348 */
349
350bool
351cfg_obj_asboolean(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
352/*%<
353 * Returns the value of a configuration object of a boolean type.
354 *
355 * Requires:
356 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of a boolean type.
357 *
358 * Returns:
359 * \li A boolean value.
360 */
361
362bool
363cfg_obj_issockaddr(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
364/*%<
365 * Return true iff 'obj' is a socket address.
366 */
367
368const isc_sockaddr_t *
369cfg_obj_assockaddr(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
370/*%<
371 * Returns the value of a configuration object representing a socket address.
372 *
373 * Requires:
374 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of a socket address type.
375 *
376 * Returns:
377 * \li A pointer to a sockaddr. The sockaddr must be copied by the caller
378 * if necessary.
379 */
380
381isc_dscp_t
382cfg_obj_getdscp(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
383/*%<
384 * Returns the DSCP value of a configuration object representing a
385 * socket address.
386 *
387 * Requires:
388 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of a
389 * socket address type.
390 *
391 * Returns:
392 * \li DSCP value associated with a sockaddr, or -1.
393 */
394
395bool
396cfg_obj_isnetprefix(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
397/*%<
398 * Return true iff 'obj' is a network prefix.
399 */
400
401void
402cfg_obj_asnetprefix(const cfg_obj_t *obj, isc_netaddr_t *netaddr,
403 unsigned int *prefixlen);
404/*%<
405 * Gets the value of a configuration object representing a network
406 * prefix. The network address is returned through 'netaddr' and the
407 * prefix length in bits through 'prefixlen'.
408 *
409 * Requires:
410 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of network prefix type.
411 *\li 'netaddr' and 'prefixlen' are non-NULL.
412 */
413
414bool
415cfg_obj_islist(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
416/*%<
417 * Return true iff 'obj' is of list type.
418 */
419
420const cfg_listelt_t *
421cfg_list_first(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
422/*%<
423 * Returns the first list element in a configuration object of a list type.
424 *
425 * Requires:
426 * \li 'obj' points to a valid configuration object of a list type or NULL.
427 *
428 * Returns:
429 * \li A pointer to a cfg_listelt_t representing the first list element,
430 * or NULL if the list is empty or nonexistent.
431 */
432
433const cfg_listelt_t *
434cfg_list_next(const cfg_listelt_t *elt);
435/*%<
436 * Returns the next element of a list of configuration objects.
437 *
438 * Requires:
439 * \li 'elt' points to cfg_listelt_t obtained from cfg_list_first() or
440 * a previous call to cfg_list_next().
441 *
442 * Returns:
443 * \li A pointer to a cfg_listelt_t representing the next element,
444 * or NULL if there are no more elements.
445 */
446
447unsigned int
448cfg_list_length(const cfg_obj_t *obj, bool recurse);
449/*%<
450 * Returns the length of a list of configure objects. If obj is
451 * not a list, returns 0. If recurse is true, add in the length of
452 * all contained lists.
453 */
454
455cfg_obj_t *
456cfg_listelt_value(const cfg_listelt_t *elt);
457/*%<
458 * Returns the configuration object associated with cfg_listelt_t.
459 *
460 * Requires:
461 * \li 'elt' points to cfg_listelt_t obtained from cfg_list_first() or
462 * cfg_list_next().
463 *
464 * Returns:
465 * \li A non-NULL pointer to a configuration object.
466 */
467
468void
469cfg_print(const cfg_obj_t *obj,
470 void (*f)(void *closure, const char *text, int textlen),
471 void *closure);
472void
473cfg_printx(const cfg_obj_t *obj, unsigned int flags,
474 void (*f)(void *closure, const char *text, int textlen),
475 void *closure);
476
477#define CFG_PRINTER_XKEY 0x1 /* '?' out shared keys. */
478#define CFG_PRINTER_ONELINE 0x2 /* print config as a single line */
479
480/*%<
481 * Print the configuration object 'obj' by repeatedly calling the
482 * function 'f', passing 'closure' and a region of text starting
483 * at 'text' and comprising 'textlen' characters.
484 *
485 * If CFG_PRINTER_XKEY the contents of shared keys will be obscured
486 * by replacing them with question marks ('?')
487 */
488
489void
490cfg_print_grammar(const cfg_type_t *type,
491 void (*f)(void *closure, const char *text, int textlen),
492 void *closure);
493/*%<
494 * Print a summary of the grammar of the configuration type 'type'.
495 */
496
497bool
498cfg_obj_istype(const cfg_obj_t *obj, const cfg_type_t *type);
499/*%<
500 * Return true iff 'obj' is of type 'type'.
501 */
502
503void
504cfg_obj_attach(cfg_obj_t *src, cfg_obj_t **dest);
505/*%<
506 * Reference a configuration object.
507 */
508
509void
510cfg_obj_destroy(cfg_parser_t *pctx, cfg_obj_t **obj);
511/*%<
512 * Delete a reference to a configuration object; destroy the object if
513 * there are no more references.
514 *
515 * Require:
516 * \li '*obj' is a valid cfg_obj_t.
517 * \li 'pctx' is a valid cfg_parser_t.
518 */
519
520void
521cfg_obj_log(const cfg_obj_t *obj, isc_log_t *lctx, int level,
522 const char *fmt, ...)
523 ISC_FORMAT_PRINTF(4, 5);
524/*%<
525 * Log a message concerning configuration object 'obj' to the logging
526 * channel of 'pctx', at log level 'level'. The message will be prefixed
527 * with the file name(s) and line number where 'obj' was defined.
528 */
529
530const char *
531cfg_obj_file(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
532/*%<
533 * Return the file that defined this object.
534 */
535
536unsigned int
537cfg_obj_line(const cfg_obj_t *obj);
538/*%<
539 * Return the line in file where this object was defined.
540 */
541
542const char *
543cfg_map_firstclause(const cfg_type_t *map, const void **clauses,
544 unsigned int *idx);
545const char *
546cfg_map_nextclause(const cfg_type_t *map, const void **clauses,
547 unsigned int *idx);
548
549typedef isc_result_t
550(pluginlist_cb_t)(const cfg_obj_t *config, const cfg_obj_t *obj,
551 const char *plugin_path, const char *parameters,
552 void *callback_data);
553/*%<
554 * Function prototype for the callback used with cfg_pluginlist_foreach().
555 * Called once for each element of the list passed to cfg_pluginlist_foreach().
556 * If this callback returns anything else than #ISC_R_SUCCESS, no further list
557 * elements will be processed.
558 *
559 * \li 'config' - the 'config' object passed to cfg_pluginlist_foreach()
560 * \li 'obj' - object representing the specific "plugin" stanza to be processed
561 * \li 'plugin_path' - path to the shared object with plugin code
562 * \li 'parameters' - configuration text for the plugin
563 * \li 'callback_data' - the pointer passed to cfg_pluginlist_foreach()
564 */
565
566isc_result_t
567cfg_pluginlist_foreach(const cfg_obj_t *config, const cfg_obj_t *list,
568 isc_log_t *lctx, pluginlist_cb_t callback,
569 void *callback_data);
570/*%<
571 * For every "plugin" stanza present in 'list' (which in turn is a part of
572 * 'config'), invoke the given 'callback', passing 'callback_data' to it along
573 * with a fixed set of arguments (see the definition of the #pluginlist_cb_t
574 * type). Use logging context 'lctx' for logging error messages. Interrupt
575 * processing if 'callback' returns something else than #ISC_R_SUCCESS for any
576 * element of 'list'.
577 *
578 * Requires:
579 *
580 * \li 'config' is not NULL
581 * \li 'callback' is not NULL
582 *
583 * Returns:
584 *
585 * \li #ISC_R_SUCCESS if 'callback' returned #ISC_R_SUCCESS for all elements of
586 * 'list'
587 * \li first 'callback' return value which was not #ISC_R_SUCCESS otherwise
588 */
589
590ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
591
592#endif /* ISCCFG_CFG_H */
593
